This is not a flash in the pan place, but a sweet, honest, and really delicious Chinese food standard that has stood the test of time. I would recommend pretty much all of the chef's specialties, getting a pot of tea, and taking time with the food and some good conversation.  Highly recommended.
author: Dan S.

description:
I've gotten takeout and dine-in from this place a couple more times, and regrettably, I have to ding them a star.  The other night, I got the chow fun with beef, and as often is the case with Chinese restaurants, the beef was super tender, but also lacking in flavor.  This, I don't understand.  What happens to the beef that deprives it of both texture and flavor??

Another time, I got the Hong Kong Style Noodles, delivered, and I was appalled by how greasy the thing was.  On the other hand, they were HK noodles, so really, I can't complain too much here.
author: Ken Y.

description:
Was having a rough day.  Pregnant and hearing voices, which tends to make one confused and disoriented... So I read about this place, Jasmine Tea House, and decided to try to order from them.

I had a hard time making my order and I initially told them the wrong address - but in spite of that, they were very patient with me.

I ordered vegetable delight, asparagus with black bean sauce, the complementary vegetable chow mein that comes with two entrees, steamed rice, and vegetable potstickers.

They came in half an hour, and only charged me $24. They were very polite. I gave them a $3 tip.

In spite of my difficulty with ordering, it was all there!  With extra sauce, utensils, and fortune cookies.

The asparagus with black bean sauce was wonderfully saucy, with onions and bell peppers.  The asparagus was nice and crisp and juicy, done to perfection.

The chow mein noodles were subtly flavorful, not too greasy, with lots of fresh vegetables - bok choy, broccoli, cabbage... (a lot of cruciferous veggies, huh?)  I've always had trouble eating greasy foods, so it was a pleasant surprise to find them without too much, instead chewy and good.  I put a little of the black bean sauce from the asparagus dish on it, and it tasted even better. :)

The vegetable delight was perfect, mild with crisp veggies - bok choy, mushrooms, broccoli, carrots, lettuce... It dripped on me a bit, but that's because they didn't scrimp on the sauce.  With all the dishes, they filled the containers all the way, and the balance between sauces and veggies was always perfect.  I never felt like they were stingy about the main course. :)

I saved the potstickers for last - mmmm! Yummm!  They had a hint of ginger in them, and though they were slightly greasy to the touch (as you'd expect) they weren't dripping in grease.  They were full, hearty potstickers... doughy and good with the right amount of veggies inside. I just need to put a little soy sauce on them to make them perfect.

All in all, the food, the service, are great.  I highly recommend the asparagus in black bean sauce, especially much - it was my favorite out of all the dishes.  It was perfect for ordering delivery, perfect food to mellow out a confusing day (and for the little one!).

Thank you, Jasmine Tea House, I'll be back. ;)
author: Yvea E.

description:
Vegetarian or not, you'll like the "fake chicken" at this place. I was brought to Jasmine Tea House by a vegetarian friend and she said, you have to try the fake meat. At first I was apprehensive since I've had the fake meats sold at Safeway and have never been satisfied, but I still gave it a shot and I'm so glad I did. I recommend the sesame or garlic chicken with the fake meat - the "meat" is fried so it's crispy on the outside but has a spongyish texture on the inside which I'd say was similar to ground chicken. The sauces on their food is very good, sometimes on the saltish side, so it goes great with the "meat."

Jasmine Tea house is a great place for lunch because of their long list of lunch specials which only cost you a whopping $5.25-6.25! What a deal and typically I'm left with leftovers to take home/back to work for a late afternoon snack.
author: Nicole L.

description:
Yes, everyone knows dim sum is best enjoyed straight off a cart, but sometimes you just want someone to bring you a couple of shrimp dumplings and a pork bun.

Anything I've ordered from this place has been above average quality, especially for delivery.
author: erik h.

description:
So I went to a benefit for Rocket Dog and finally got to meet the illustrious Laura B. While I did make it in time for the last stashed away vegan cupcake, I missed the sesame chicken with fake meat from Jasmine Tea House. Laura raved about how fantastic it was. So as soon as I got my car back from the shop, I drove on over and picked some up!

I must say, for all the stellar reviews of the fake chicken on this board, I was a lil disappointed. I guess as far as fake chicken goes, it had good texture. But I have come to two conclusions: 1) maybe I am vegan because I just don't love chicken and 2) even if it is a good replica for the real thing, all it's replicating it greasy, breaded, fried chinese food. I forgot how nasty easting chinese food makes me feel! Plus they put egg in my veggie fried rice. I know I should have asked them not to (I forgot), but I sorta thought that if they were serving me fake meat they wouldn't egg up my rice. Oh well...at least the rice was free.

Now that my curiosity is satisfied, I doubt I'll be back.
author: Cindy R.

description:
We have been living in Mission/Noe area for almost 3 years now and still looking for good Chinese food. When I saw all the reviews here I decided to try it. Frankly I'm not sure what the fuss is all about. Maybe this place is popular because of the vegetarian choices. I'm not a vegetarian.

Sesame Beef was way over-sauced. The pieces of beef were swimming in the sauce. The chicken and green beans dish was bland. The vegetable chow mein was totally without flavor. It seemed like it was missing salt or something.

I am going to try this place again because I believe that you have to give a restaurant at least two tries before you make a judgment. After my second try, I will come back and either adjust my rating or leave it as is.

The search for decent Chinese food in Mission/Noe continues.
author: Reza E.

description: Great food and Great service.  We are vegetarians and the meatless chicken is great!  You can get any dish with meatless chicken or beef. Service is good and staff is friendly.  Cute little place to eat.  Great veggie pot stickers. yummy!  Been coming here for last 3-4 years.  Right now remodeling..can't wait to go back.
author: Glam K.

description:
It took me a long time to realize that JTH has become my benchmark for chinese restaurants.  Every time I order from or eat at any other Chinese Food Restaurant in the city, I always find myself comparing their food to the food from Jasmine Tea House.  JTH's fare is an exact fit for your craving when you think you want some "chinese food just like you used to get from that hometown chinese restaurant."

Their dining room isn't fancy, but it is clean and usually a good place for conversation.  Their delivery service is excellent, I have been a  long time customer and I have never had a mix up.  I recommend the Lemon Chicken.
author: Gusty S.

description:
Consistently good flavors and service. 

This is the place that you wish was everyone's neighborhood Chinese restaurant. As generic as won ton soup can be the combo won ton soup topped with sauteed pieces of chicken in brown sauce and shrimp along with fresh greens and mushroom was delicious. (all you'll need is a bowl, to save room for the other dishes) 

We also enjoyed some sizzling beef table side. You can't go wrong with the dishes in the Chef's special section.

We also noticed that they have many veggie options for dim sum and have highlighted on their menu, that they create their own meatless chicken on premises.

They also have free delivery for lunch and are open for dinner til 10pm on Sundays (which is a hard thing to find in SF, for some reason)
author: Helen J.

description:
Just ate a wonderful dinner from this place.  Called the restaurant about 30 minutes ago and delivery guy came by my house really quickly!  I mean...Pizza Hut takes even longer to deliver a pizza than it takes Jasmine to deliver fried rice, soup, and 2 entrees!  

When compared to the other Chinese restaurants on the Bernal side of Mission, this is definitely the best.  The person who took my order was pleasant and so was delivery guy.   

Their fried rice is flavorful, not so greasy like the others I've had before.  Their lemon chicken kinda looks like chicken katsu with lemon sauce, but good nonetheless.   I'd definitely order again the next time "I'm lazy to cook" night comes around.

In terms of price, their menu items are reasonable.  Tonight's dinner with tip was $25  for a dinner for two.  The food quality and quick service is worth every penny!
author: Raymond G.

description:
UPDATE: movement in the star category: 3 to a 4
OK, I finally went back and this time we ate there and had a great meal: won ton and sweet and sour soups--we could not make up our mind so we got both; BBQ ribs to keep my girl happy , broccoli and chicken, and brown rice. It was simple and very tasty. No more take out for me--I will take the 3 minute walk and eat there.

I have lived around the corner from JTH for 6 months and finally ordered take out last night. It was decent. We ordered dim sum: shrimp dumplings and pork bun (they give you 3 pieces per order--just an FYI because we ordered too much); garlic chicken which I could not taste any garlic--it was good but not what I was expecting; sweet and sour pork--average; and fried rice, also average. I will go back and make my way through some of the recommendations of other Yelpers. I have faith I will find a new culinary addiction here, but it was not in last night's order.
author: Deborah S.

description: I shouldn't be ordering from them because as a vegan i cannot tell if their food is actually vegan...but if they had meatless orange chicken, I would be OH SO HAPPY!
author: Natalie M.

description:
Well, I knew I wouldn't be disappointed when I saw the signature round Yelp sticker in the door of the Jasmine Tea House.

After giving a friend a ride back to his house in SF from Modesto last night, we needed some major grubbage before the journey back to the Valley. So, being that our friend lives in Bernal Heights, the Jasmine was a short two block walk away.

At first, I felt the service was a bit slow seeing as that it wasn't busy but, when our order was finally taken, the waitress was friendly as hell. This is the first time I've ever seen the waitress/waiter actually write the order down in Chinese! I thought that was a nice touch.

Within 10 minutes, our food started to arrive. We ordered Orange Chicken, Veggie chow mein, and Mongolian beef. All of it was spicy but all of it was wonderful! Between the three of us, we nearly cleared all three plates, and left with the feeling of satisfaction.

I had read somewhere that Yelp has helped improve the service of restaurants in the city, and If this place was any inclination to that being true, I don't know what is.

Also to note: Their beer, sake and wine is very affordable. A small Sapporo or Anchor Steam is a mere $3.25. I'd be hard pressed to find cheaper beer in the city. They were also named to SF's Best of San Francisco in 2006 for a couple of their dishes.
author: Kristin P.

description:
One time I ate lunch at this Chinese food place by my work... 
I drove back to my office, and decided it was too nice to go back inside.
...I'll just sit in my car, listen to the radio and crack open the window to enjoy the bright breezy day for a little bit...
Forty minutes later, I woke up.  
That's the thing about a lot of Chinese food places, they make me feel heavy and sluggish afterward. 

...but not Jasmine Tea House. The dim sum is really fresh, and the food is delicately done. Definitely a fan. It's my new default Chinese place.
author: Darlene S.

description:
Mao's Pork? Count me in.

Sure, it wasn't hot, but it was still good. Made me wonder what kind of cat came up with it.

A hep cat? A cool cat? Or a tasty, slightly garlicky sauteed cat? Mmmm, lucky kitty's paws.

The food here is great, super affordable, and they have a great selection. Don't forget the Ostrich, it's good, as is the absolutely tasty asparagus with black beans.

Food comes quick, and food for pickup is packed very well. Overall, this place is great.
author: Dave M.

description:
This is a special place.  Eight years ago I started taking my daughter out for a date.  Jasmine became our favorite place.  Today we continue to bring our friends and all three of my children count this as a favorite spot.

Great lunch specials, always consistent.  Love the sweet and sour soups and everything with brown rice.  The jasmine tea always a family favorite.  Parking can be challenging but take out is always a win.

Best of all, Frank, thanks for blessing my children!  Your food is awesome but the memories priceless.
author: Ken M.

description: I love this restaurant~ Every time I visit the food and service are outstanding... my favorites are the Happy Buddha and Jasmine Prawns, but I'm also partial to the spicy dry green beans and the shrimp dumplings. PLUS they serve sake~!~  Fantastic.
author: SisterMable S.

description:
JTH is my "go to" Chinese restaurant in the neighborhood!  Everything I've ordered has been good...and not in a "okay, kind of good way," but the really, really good 'n' tasty way!  A few must orders:

Combo Clay Pot
Meatless Chicken w/green beans and asparagus (this isn't on menu)
Sizzling Beef
Hot and Sour Soup

I didn't think the Jasmine Prawn was over the top good, but I didn't  return it to the kitchen either!

Oh yeah, order two entrees to go and they give you a FREE fried rice or chow mein.

Now, how can you beat that?!?
author: Josh M.

description:
Since I can't go to Eric's any more, this is now my new go-to Chinese food place. It accells in what it should: quick, no frills food. The place was clean and the people friendly. We ordered and picked it up. The sign was a bit difficult to find, for some odd reason. 

The Jasmine Prawn was underwhelming, the Veggie Mu Shu tasty, the Kung Pao Meatless Chicken quite tasty (but the veggies were a little bland, but the tofu was wonderful), the ninjas were a nice touch. 

Wait, you didn't see 'em? They were in stealth mode...
author: Benjamin T.

description:
I first investigated this place at the advice of other Yelpers, and I've been continually pleased - its close proximity to where I live also makes it a good destination if I'm feeling up to getting on the 14.

The other reviews are spot on about the chicken - I've not had better veggie chicken in all of the Bay, and I keep trying it elsewhere as well.  The orange fake chicken is particularly good (not on the menu, I don't think) and so is the curry fake chicken - they're happy to substitute mock chicken for real chicken on anything they have, and both ordering via phone and in the restaurant they've been nothing but amenable when I feel like trying something creative or unlisted.

Loses a star, however, because the pure tofu dishes really just aren't that great (kung pao tofu, etc); as a vegetarian, you're better off sticking with the faux meat.  Note that delivery times can sometimes take a while.

Update:

It's been a few months since my last review.  I have ordered from here so many times that I actually know some of the people by name and by voice over the phone (Hi, Alex!).  No joke, I think I have food from this place -every other day-.

They're cheap (the lunch specials are always more than enough food, and they serve them until 5), they're good, and they're reliable.  I have a set time for a lunch break where I work (out in Soma, at 8th and Townsend), and I know they're good enough that I can order at a specific time and receive it right before my break -- not to mention that they'll seriously take it *all the way out there*, providing it's not just me ordering one $6 special.

If you're a veggie and order a tofu dish, shame on you.  Their meatless chicken is the stuff of legends.  It's so good that I take meat eaters here and they stick with the meatless dishes.  You can't go wrong.  Mmm.  Jasmine Tea House, my love.
author: Juliette S.

description: Why did you do this to me Jasmine?! You had the best wonton soup my mouth has ever come in contact with! I will miss you dearest
author: Astrid I.

description:
I love JTH for so many reasons...I love that it was the first chinese take-out I ever had in the mission, on the first or second day I moved here, a friend invited me over to her house after a long night of bar-hopping and she had like 8 different take-out dishes from JTH just laying around from earlier that night...it hit the spot in a way that I'll never forget that night. 

I also love the multi-colored neon light-up sign outside of JTH that, to me, looks more "massage parlor" than "quality chinese cuisine." And I love that they tout the fact (on their webpage) that President Clinton ate at JTH when he was visiting San Francisco! I love that I can count on JTH as a sanctuary of sorts, where I can get a good meal in a mellow, calming environment when I am stressed out. And I love that the servers do that whole formal, one-hand-behind-the-back thing when they are pouring water into your glass or serving you soup! Marvelous!
author: Shannon R.

description:
For hole-in-the-wall Chinese, its hard to beat.  Especially if you are already in the neighborhood.

Pros: Very affordable.  The lunch special is the best part.  One can get a main dish w/rice and sweet/sour soup for $6 (and this much food can feed two).  Their dishes (which are a assortment) have very high quality ingredients.  And what I mean by that is the chicken is all wonderfully tasty white meat.  You never get a bite of that mystery stuff that just wont allow itself to be chewed.  Their veggies are also super-fresh.  The staff is all very friendly and the service is top-notch.  Being right on Mission, it is also very easy to get to via bus, car, or the J line.  Park is also not too hard to come by either.

Cons: atmosphere is not that of a 5-star restaurant.  I almost don't even think it is worth mentioning except for the fact it is one of few identifiable places where they could improve.  Culinary skills also seem to be inconsistent.  I have had my chicken VERY well done.  But, better overdone than underdone chicken.  

Well done Jasmine Tea House!  Maybe I'll see you for lunch.
author: Nicholas S.

description:
Despite their claim to be a "Mandarin Chinese Food" restaurant, I always hear the staff at Jasmine Tea House jabbering in Cantonese, and they'll make you crispy Hong Kong style chow mein if you ask for it.

Interestingly, the best dish here is the fried rice. It's salty and delicious and the best I've had in the area. Their other dishes are pretty good, and true to their name, they serve a good pot of fresh brewed jasmine tea (they also have a wide selection of other Chinese teas).

Their staff is pretty friendly and gives suggestions (although be warned, when they're speaking in Chinese to each other in the background sometimes they're making fun of you). We live nearby and their delivery is always fast (usually 15-20 minutes) and the food still hot and fresh.
author: Andrew H.

description:
I look forward to visiting friends in Bernal just so we can get takeout from Jasmine Tea House.

Pea sprouts in garlic sause, and the faux lemon chicken are standouts.
author: kellan e.

description:
I've had food delievered twice from this place, and both times I was utterly underwhelmed. Blame it on the delivery, or blame it on my lackluster feelings for Chinese food if you must. You know what I say, give em' a second chance, but never a third.

Sadly, everything we got tasted (and looked) exactly the same--soaked in soy sauce. It wasn't horrible, but it was just really "eh." You know, one of those meal that you keep eating while you continue to complain about it. The mu shu was a soggy mess of jumbled ingredients that were unidentifiable. The mu shu pancakes were too thin and the ones that weren't all stuck together tore easily. The zuchini was chopped in very large hunks and undercooked. The Kung Pao Meatless chicken was invaded by soy sauce too. And wouldn't you know it, they threw in some extra packets---like a foot in my ass kicking me out the door, never to return. Of course, I've never been cuz I'm too lazy to get up and go there.
author: Stumbalina b.

description:
I've really enjoyed this place, both for delivery and sit-in meals. I order more frequently for delivery as I live on the top of a hill and am often reluctant to leave home unless I know a car will bring me back, and they are routinely delivering prompt, hot, accurate orders with a smile. I've tried both the standard fare (Broccoli Beef, Lemon Chicken, etc) and more individual plates (Shanghai Filet, Yangtze Ribs) and always felt like I got a good meal at a fair price. 

Sitting in, however, is anywhere from a 10 to 20 percent better experience, because the food is hotter (and every bit matters with items like crab puffs) and fresher.
author: Ian M.

description:
What a huge let down! Cloying gloppy sweet, disgusting .. terrible.  A lot must've has happened since 2002 when Clinton ordered it and they got a Best Of from SF Weekly in 2006, they must have new owners.  This wasn't attributable to an off night, this was their style.  To make things worse, we dined in. A creepy place way past it's prime.  Dirty glass tops and gross stains on table cloths .. and at every table. Eeewww. Stay away.  Clinton stays away now and it's not just because of his bad heart.  Yuck!

WOW I MISS YET WAH !!!!!!!
author: Matt W.

description: I really like this place. The staff is super helpful and friendly and patient. Their dim sum is awesome and they deliver it too for a ten dollar minimum--perfect for those nights when you're too lazy to turn off your Neil Young MTV Unplugged VHS and drag yourself off the couch to get it yourself. They have tons of meatless stuff and their sesame balls are better than Yank Sing. I'm ecstatic that this place is basically two blocks down Mission from my house. Jasmine I love you.
author: Laura M.

description:
Really laid-back atmosphere.  Even though it was getting close to closing time when we were finishing our meal, they didn't rush us or any of the other three remaining parties to leave.  It was really nice to sit for a bit after the meal and finish our tea and digest (di-what?), which I realized is something I practically never do.  At most places (or the ones I frequent, anyway), they often want you out literally before you've finished your meal.  Maybe it's more hectic here at busier times, but I really enjoyed and appreciated the relaxed vibe.

If I'd have Yelped before I went, I would have tried the apparently famous chickenless chicken, but we went on a whim, so no recommendations to go by.  The real chicken was pretty good though.  I had it sauteed with string beans, which were crunchy and well-seasoned, and the bf had it deep fried and Szechwan sauced to such perfection that it tasted like candy (seriously).  

Friendly and fast service, reasonable prices, we'll be back.
author: Megan D.

description:
This is a wonderful place.

08/10/2008 Sorry, I am going to annaly retentively withdraw one star. Quality has dropped. Don't know why. Maybe it's me. But life is unfair and Jasmine will suffair.
author: Bobby T.

description:
Best Chinese in the Mish, thats for sure.

The food IS on/off from time to time, which I am ok with...because I only order for one thing:

Fried Sesame Tofu (think Sesame Chicken without the nasty gristle or possibility of icky badly fried meat).

This dish was served to me first by a boy I really liked. The boy was quickly gone, but my loyalty to Jasmine remained strong.

It delivers pretty quickly, the thing I order is always amazing and delicious...and sometimes they even throw in a free hot and sour soup (which I also really like).

My housemates have eaten some of the other stuff from here and say its either amazing one day or lackluster another...however I am personally always pleased.

Overall, a decent joint to not be on the EC :)
author: Rylan S.

description:
This is good food. Not jump up and down tell all your friends we gotta network this joint good food, but... I 'd say it's a cute little place to meet your family in (and that's what we did). The service is great, it's clean and very accommodating. Their pot stickers are very yummy.

I'd say I mostly like it because it's a calm place to bring little one, and that's important.
author: Catherine H.

description: This restaurant offers tasty food for bargain prices.  $7 gets you a heaping lunch special that is closer to two meals than one.  While the decor is a bit baffling, the service is prompt, and the food very enjoyable.
author: Andy A.

description:
Not bad at all. I've been going here on and off for a few year. (Grew up in the neighborhood) There are a bunch of things on the menu that I really like, but it's hit and miss. The oolong duck was awful. The taste of the tea did nothing for the duck. On the contrary it took all the juice and sweetness out of the meat. 

The highlights however! Oh that mango prawn salad. Not what you would expect at a chinese place, but oh so good. The soups are generally quite good. Their peking duck is wonderful!! 

On the whole, there are other places I'd prefer (see my last review), but if you know what to order you'll leave quite satisfied.
author: Mindy L.

description: their delivery service is very fast, I had ordered some food online and it only took like 20 mins, when my food was arrived I was surprising because it was so fast, and I got the guys' name, he is sheng.  he also told me that if i call in to order two or moreitems ,i can get  . waw! such a good deal. I think I will ask him for delivery next time. this is a very good service restaurant, their food is delicious and fresh. Also i strongly recommend their tai tea, it is very good. jasmine tea house is the best Chinese restaurant I ever tried, it got the five stars.
author: Janice S.

description:
I had a little dinner her with a friend on Thursday; and if I hadn't read the reviews about the restaurant on yelp before hand I don't think I would have gone into the restaurant. The exterior looks very tacky!! But, the inside the restaurant is cute and comfortable. 
The food was good; we order a few different appetizers. I would pass on the combination wonton soup; the shrimp dim sum was forgettable, not bad but nothing amazing. I will however recommend the vegetarian mu shu, that the waiter rolled table side. 
In saying that the service was very good! Almost surprisingly good for the price points of the food. The staff was very attentive and friendly. 
I want to go back to try their entrees.
author: Marie-Claire R.

description:
3.5 stars for the vegetarian dim sum.  

As a vegetarian, I almost have to swear off dim sum since most of these Chinese small plates have pork or seafood in them.  We stopped by here Jasmin Tea house one Saturday afternoon and stumbled across the "large" vegetarian dim sum selection. I ordered Steamed Tofu Roll (3), Vegetable Dumpling (3), Chive Dumpling (3) and liked them in that order.  The name Steamed Tofu Roll isn't very descriptive for those of you who are new to dim sum; they are in fact steamed fried tofu skin wrapped around julienne veggies. The normal version often comes with dice pork and shrimp and Jasmine Tea House does a fine vegetarian version.  The Vegetable Dumplings and Chive Dumplings are pretty good as well although the dumpling skin is a little on the thick side. In order for me to be full at say Yank Sing, I would probably need 4 plates of dim sums all to myself.  The dumplings/servings at the Jasmine Tea House are huge.  I basically ate half and pack the rest home.  At $2.95 each, the price is right.  Also love the fact that they don't break/close in the afternoon unlike most Chinese restaurants.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Hey everyone, don't tell the people at Jasmine Tea House that they could charge twice as much, act rude, give smaller portions and be just like Eliza's! Jasmine Tea House is perfect as it is.

We were surprised that such a low-key neighborhood place had more than their share of unusual dishes, like the Basil Ostrich. Basically, it's just as good as what you'd get at Eliza's or Eric's, but the prices are more in line with low-end places. I highly recommend the Ginger Chicken and the Sizzling Beef.

The service is also very good. One time we were wondering what pea sprouts were -- they were listed in the description for one of the dishes. The waiter described them and we ordered something else. When our food came, the waiter also brought a smaller version of the dish with pea sprouts for us to try. Glad he did -- they were good!
author: Scott K.

description:
MMm, delicious! I've been going to this place ever since the owners split off from the Garden of Tranquility (circa 2000).  I'm Chinese myself and I can say that this place serves very authentic Mandarin food. It has a menu that diversifies greatly from standard "Chinese" fare---it's for the most part non-greasy and with complex flavors--it's not just chow mein and sesame chicken here! I recommend the eggplant dishes, you can also even order crab if you call in ahead of time.

And come on, Bill Clinton approves.

Update: I just tried their meatless chicken (in both sesame and sweet n sour morphos), and I feel compelled to award them +1 shiny red star. It possesses both sumptuous flavor --definitely tofu derived, and best when hot--and ingenious texturization--it's not as dense as tofu... it seriously has the flakiness of real meat.

This place kicks Mekong's inferior *puke* TVP chick to the curb. BAM!
author: T.Z. R.

description:
Just because a joint serves Americanized or "westernized" Chinese food does not make it bad. Call me crazy, and I might be a little, but sometimes that fried General Tsao's Chicken and Mongolian Beef with broccoli just hits the spot. I am from a town of 420 people (last count, 2000 US Census), where the nearest Chinese place served more fried dishes than the county fair, so you can see how I have that "spot". Sometimes it's just what you need.

I don't usually give five stars unless a places offers something *extra*. The fact that this place delivers to my house in Bayview bumps them up from a well-earned four stars.
author: Kathryn C.

description:
I'm so tired of the snooty Yelp writers ragging on New-York-style Chinese food!  I mean, not *everything* one consumes has to be insanely priced, overly complex fusion of African, Asian, and Martian flavors to be damned good food!  Don't taze me, bro, when I say that sometimes the mundane classic is the best choice.

Jasmine Tea House is just that place.  It's flavors are simple and reminiscent of those Chinese take-out places in New York.

To put it in perspective, I am Italian and I grew up in a Jewish neighborhood.  We know *all* about Chinese food.  When I die and go to Heaven, all my Jewish friends waiting for me will have a bowl of Won Ton soup and a fat eggroll waiting for me--you know, the kind that is a deep fried Chinese burrito filled with cabbage that turned red from the roast pork inside.  No, none of this test tube phyllo dough "spring roll" crapola that Californians pass off as an appetizer...

You can tell a good place by how they handle the fried rice.  Fried rice should be lightly brown with delicate flavors, onions, eggs, and roast (in California, BBQ) pork.  The only thing missing would be the bean sprouts.  I ask them to throw them in for me, and they seldom disappoint.

Point being, Jasmine Tea House nails the flavors us New Yorkers *know* to be *real* Chinese food-- you know, the kind that I'll find waiting for me in Heaven when I die.
author: Danny C.

description:
The absolute best vegan soy chicken in the city. Nah sir the State. Perhaps even the country. In any case amazing. 

Looking even if you love the meat and you are just veggie-curious check it out. Even my meaters friends be lovin'

oh yeah and they deliver, and they have lunch specials (which are huge) and the services is pretty friggin amazing. Go Go now
author: Vasile S.

description:
When I need top-notch faux chicken, this is where I go.  Last time I ate here, I got a $40 parking ticket because I accidentally let my meter expire.  When I saw the ticket, I didn't cringe or flinch.  I was so deep-down happy after my meal that I was completely unfazed.  Now that's saying something.  

I have heard good things from meat-eaters as well.  I took my step-dad here, and he raved about his dish (made with the real chicken) for probably a week.

Yeah.  Go.
author: Veggie J.

description: Delivery took about an hour, about average. The General Tsao's Chicken was pretty soggy on arrival and on the saltier side rather than sweet, not spicey at all even though I requested it extra spicey, decent but a dissapointment. Crab puffs a little better than average, potstickers were definitely good. All in all a little better than average and I may hit it up again sometime but the bottom line is that my search for a go to chinese delivery joint in SF continues...
author: M L.

description: Jasmine Tea House is my fav chinese food in SF, well anywhere really...it doesn't leave you with that greased down kinda gross feeling you get after eating most chinese food. They have yummy general chicken (we order with the sauce on the side yum) and their fried rice is good too, their dry garlic prawns super yummy :) The staff are very nice and it's a cozy spot for dining in, take-out or delivery! Try it out! Super yummy!
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Rolled into this joint at the GF's suggestion. We were rollin' to the Mission for tacos, when suddenly we were possessed with the need for Chinese. She quickly recalled a place she'd eaten while her ma was in town.

The place is really nice...well adorned with authentic Chinese items...not cheesy plastic and no neon stuff.  The bathroom had this really cool mirror with a nice frame and a cast iron mural of a Chinese street scene.

Anyway, we order mixed veggies, an excellent pot sticker soup(can't remember the exact name), a chicken clay pot and jasmine tea. The tea you pay for, but it  comes out in a really cool tea pot and is really nice. 

The meal was reasonably priced, the service was friendly and efficient and the decor was classy not cheesy. I'm only knocking 1/2 a star because the food wasn't as spicy as I would have liked. However, the waiter brought me two different spicy sauces, which still wasn't spicy enough for me, but it was the thought that counted. So overall 4.5 stars!

I will be back for more!
author: isaias J.

description:
I love this place! Great food, great prices, the seasonal items are great (mango chicken & shrimp). It can get pretty busy in there, but their specialty items are totally worth getting a table, ordering in, or walking over. The delivery deal where you get two entree's and get a  a free item, is pretty hard to beat as well.

Update- My heart is literally broken :(
author: Niki M.

description:
I've had take-out from here 3 or 4 times now. Items seem slightly hit or miss...nothing is bad, but from the reviews here, I expected everything to be fantastic. I was exited to try the mock-chicken as I'm a big fan of the fake meat--I thought it was just ok. Though, I did not have the sesame fake chicken that everyone raves about--I didn't see it on the menu. I did have a "to-die-for" sesame noodle salad though--so maybe "sesame" is their thing? 

When Jasmine's good, it's awesome! Just takes some trying to find the right things.
author: Wendy G.

description:
So I really did not feel like leaving the house, and I had read on Yelp that these guys deliver.  The delivery went smoothly and the guy showed up pretty quickly - that is the end of the good stuff.  

I ordered tofu chow fun and it did not taste like anything.  No smoky wok flavor, no sharp scallions, no nothing.  It was so bland that I wondered if they used brown food coloring to make the noodles have color.  I knew that it could not have been from any type of sauce or seasoning.  

I also ordered the house special ginger chicken.  Perhaps it was my fault for thinking it was the version with poached chicken and a delicious fresh green onion and ginger sauce on the side.  Their version was gloppy and made from pickled ginger (yeah, the kind that comes on the side of your sushi).  The fact that a Chinese restaurant was not using fresh ginger was telling that this place is both bland and dumbing down the flavor for their customers.  I will not be going back or ordering in again.
author: Dana H.

description: I ordered delivery and when I received the wrong order, I was told I was wrong and was argued with. They picked up the order and refused to refund me. So, I ended up without food and my money. I called Eat24 (the app I used to place the order). They also argued with me and it wasn't until I was persistent that they finally gave me credit.
author: J L.

description:
If you live in the Upper Noe/Bernal Heights area, you gotta check this place out.  This is our "standard" Chinese takeout place and it's perfect for a family like ours with both meat eaters and vegetarians.  Their noodles are great (try the Hong Kong style noodles!) and their "faux" chicken entrees are excellent.  Coming from a meat lover like myself, that's saying a lot.  Eric's and Alice's don't compare to this place.

Updated 2/25/07:  I don't know if it's just me, but the food here seems to have taken a dive of late.  I've not been happy with the dinners I've had delivered the last few times so I'm removing one star.  I'm thinking about finding another place for Chinese delivery, but will probably give Jasmine Tea House one last shot.
author: Sharyn F.

description:
Ok, so I crave Chinese food like once every-other month...and MUST have it.  

We kinda had not great experiences with delivery time, food temperature, and food quality the last couple of times we called House of Chen...so we thought we'd give Jasmine a try.

AWESOME chicken fried rice.  WONDERFUL pork pot stickers.  Just average on the kung pao chicken.  But they told us it would be 30-45 minutes (average) and we got our food in literally 15 minutes.  No joke.  I'm sure it isn't and won't be like this all the time - but the food was hot and really very good.  The fortune cookies were even better tasting than I remember HOC being...

We'll continue to order from here for now.  Yeah for Jasmine Tea House!
author: Kelly M.

description: Love this place. this is one of my favorite spots for chinese food. The service is very helpful and friendly the food was on fire tonight. I like this place and am almost always satisfied!. two thumbs up for the Jasmine Tea House!
author: Daniel C.

description: They have "meatless chicken" which is amazing! Get that! Get that now! It is sooooo good. It is tofu that tastes like whatever kind if chicken dish you order. Everything else there is what you can find at any good chinese place in the City but that meatless chicken is just great. I think there was a whole month when I have it for dinner ever night, lol
author: Jose M.

description: Man... this place IS NOT CLOSED!   If you call the phone number, you will see that it is merely "CLOSED FOR REMODELING". JTH 2.0 COMING SOON!!!!!!
author: Nino D.

description:
Mother of god do I love this place. Really. Meatless chicken? Check. Amazing peanut sauce? Check. Mochi? Check. 

The last time I was here was just a couple of weeks ago; it was almost 10 on a Saturday night and a few of us really, really wanted to go here and it was a gamble considering how late we were, but they sat us anyway! The server was honest and said that the kitchen was closing soon so we had to order fast, and we did, and the food showed up even faster, and as delicious as it usually is. When places are about to close, I've had terrible luck with the quality of food, but it was just as good as it was if we'd walked in at 8. They didn't pressure us to leave soon after eating and we got to enjoy our dining experience, which speaks volumes about this place if they weren't pressuring patrons to leave despite the late hour. 

The food is here is always amazing and has been a favorite destination for years. It's great for medium to large groups of people and you can share each plate, so don't hesitate to order just a few dishes. The onion cakes are a must, and so is the sweet and sour meatless chicken. I would inject it into my veins if I could without, you know, dying.
author: Paul W.

description:
The Jasmine Tea House is one reason I am sad not to live in Bernal Heights anymore.  This Chinese restaurant is welcoming in an unassuming, non-pretentious way.  The wait staff has always been accommodating, sweet, and helpful.  One of the waiters had/has a major crush on a friend of mine, so much so that it got to be a little embarrassing going in there with her because the flirting was out of control.  But it was nothing that could keep us away from the tasty treats that Jasmine Tea House has to offer.

The wonton soup is chock-full of deliciousness and is one of my favorites -- I appreciate their generous portion of wontons with the thinnest dumpling dough ever.  A large is more than a meal.

And the dim sum options are fun if you feel like tasting a bit of this and a bit of that before the main event.
author: Sharon R.

description:
Used to like it a lot.  then i got FOOD POISONING!!!!!  Such a painful experience, I'm never going back.

Update - 1/30/07 - My boyfriend still insists on ordering from this place even tho I got sick.  He loves their food and claims that it's the best he's had in the city.  He's never gotten sick.  I just get el metate on nights that he orders from here.
author: Melissa Y.

description:
This place is Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde.  I have dined in and was quite pleased with the mix of dishes you come to expect and some creative ones as well.  Then, I ordered take out for a first time, Mongolian Beef I think, and was happy.  Great, a consistent Chinese place to get take-out ... more elusive than it should be in the City.

And then---blech.  I got some sort of chicken for take out and it literally was like the globs of stuff you get at those Chinese Food/Donut/Autoparts places.  (Think 24th and Mission.)  But it was even blander.

I will likely be back, because that might have been an aberration, but we shall see...
author: Paul K.

description:
Oh man!  I have never liked wonton soup - and this place has not changed the wonton part of that sentence.... but when I tried the combination wonton soup, which aside from wontons has chicken and shrimp in brown sauce - i thought to myself, "this may be the best damn soup ever!".  It tasted the way chinese food tasted when you were a kid and you thought it is the greatest food ever (next to hamburgers, pizza and tacos of course).  

All the other dishes we had were also very good.  The pickled greens - sound kind of weird, taste kinda good.

Hot & Sour soup was only dish i though was just ok - but it was vegetarian friendly.

They also deliver.
author: Greg M.

description:
My chinese Aunts always said, "Be wary of a Chinese restaurant that doesn't serve you chopsticks or tea straight off"  and, well this place didn't serve me either.  But it was damn good!
service was a big lacking...but, I'd go back.
author: Matt V.

description:
Delivery is quick and efficient.  And the food is pretty good.

I'm not a huge Chinese food fan. Although I do like me some dim sum for breakfast.

This is a good change when I get sick of Mexican, Thai, Cambodian, and Japanese. But that almost never happens.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
Definitely the best overall Chinese in the Mission.  No complaints with any of the food I've ordered, but the atmosphere is kind of generic.  Deliciously cloying "dry fried" wings.  The mapo tofu is not authentic, but still good. Especially great are the dumplings, appetizers, and tea. Service can be a problem sometimes though.

The lunch menu is ridiculously cheap given the quality. The Happy Buddha is $6.50 and includes all kinds of delicious exotic vegetables including meatless chicken, black mushrooms, wood ear, and willow tree fungus. The Hunan Lamb is awesome and only $5.25 -- when's the last time you got a lamb dish in SF for so little! I just order a bunch of different lunch dishes and throw them in the fridge for later in the week.
author: Adam Z.

description:
My coworker and I were on business here from NY.  I wanted some chinese that was not TOO TRADITIONAL (if you know what i'm saying--no chicken feet..none of that)  So after reading many yelping reviews I decided to venture out on a bus from mission and 5th.  As my coworker and I rode across mission we noticed how drastic the neighborhood changed.  It wasnt anything scary to us, it was just a bit eclectic, retro cheezy with thrift stores and pawn shops all over the place..but anyway this didnt really phase me.

I was pleased with the Jasmine Tea House.  We began with vegetarian spring rolls that were super yummy.  I had the chicken and corn soup which was super delicious and my coworker has a nice wonton soup in which she pleased to find chicken, beef, and shrimp in it (not your typical wonton soup)

For out entrees I had the mongolian beef which was super yummy!!!!!  There was a little red pepper next to the description on the menu but it wasnt hot at all =/ but it was still great.  The beef was so tender, juicy and lean.  My coworker has the szechuan beef which she loved.  The portion sizes are great, we had a lot left over.  We ended with some green tea and vanilla ice cream ...The service was nice, friendly, and quick.  Decor is cute...bathroom could use a little updating.

This was exactly the chinese I wanted.  I left very happy :)
author: Dee A.

description: Came here as I was craving some chow-mein and fried rice. A friend of mine had recommended me this place, and being only half a block away from my house I decided to try it out. Service was great and fast, small intimate place to eat. The food was good but noodles were a little bland to my taste, love that it's not overly greasy!! I would eat here again especially because it's so close.
author: Qita A.

description: Great deals for takeout and delivery. Yummy fake meat options. Reliable and lots of food for the money.
author: Ann Marie D.

description:
Dim sum to my door
Electric orange spareribs
Do the gluten Tsao
author: HaikuReview S.

description:
I believe the food is excellent, although may be best for take-out. Most of the space fills with cold air when the door opens, but you can't blame them for the weather. Everything on the walls makes it look like a good place to dine, and it's very clean.

The couple next to us had some trouble getting all their dishes at the same time and ours came at once. The Clay Pot is excellent, alongside some veggies we had with crab puffs before.

We dined here on NYE, so our expectations were a bit high and it was somewhat disappointing for us both, although the food made up for most of the experience. I'll try to order take-out next time instead.
author: Kevin D.

description:
Fighting a bad cold with a cough I found myself tired and just not up to the idea of cooking this past Sunday.  Instead of calling our usual local Chinese Restaurant (bad me) I decided to jump on Yelp and see what other Chinese restaurants there were that would deliver.  To my delight I ran across the reviews for Jasmine Tea House.  I was greeted by a woman who struggled to understand me as I inquired whether or not they would deliver to my South Beach address.  After a few minutes of repeating myself, she came back to me and said yes they would deliver but only for a min. order amount of $20 which was totally understandable.  I proceeded to order more than usual to make this limit.  Let's see now....

One order of shu mai (steamed pork dumplings) - rubbery
One order of Ha gow (steamed shrimp dumplings) - these were good
One order of egg rolls (greasy is an understatement)
One order of Hot and sour soup (this was mediocre and greasy at best)
One order of the House Special Won Ton Soup (while loaded with meat, it was so greasy that I couldn't drink the soup.  The won ton were falling apart.  Good restaurants alwyays deliver your soup separate from the won ton.)
One order of Pork Fried Rice (Can you say flavorless uncle ben's?)

All of this not so yummy goodness came to a heaping total of $40.43.  Along with this outrageous fee, was the joy of receiving cold food since our order arrived exactly 90 minutes post my call to Jasmine Tea House.

Initially I thought, wow even Bill Clinton ate here.  I then thought to myself, wait- wasn't he in the media for frequenting McDonalds?  I will definitely not be frequenting this restaurant again.  Sorry Canton Dim Sum & Seafood Restaurant, I will never cheat on you again!
author: Alicia W.

description:
Jasmine Tea House redeemed itself last night with the ostrich dish. Last weekend, I had the sesame chicken and it was horrible and the sunflower chicken was bland. All of our left overs were thrown away a week later.  

I love the crab wontons. 

Delivery is speedy and if it is going to take a long time, they let you know as your ordering so you can make a decision to pick it up or wait.
author: Melissa A.

description:
Food was consistent.  The faux paux general tsao tofu-chicken was a bit flourly..it tasted like flour, literally.  
Otherwise the eggplant, friend rice, and hong kong styled noodles were delicious.  
Also the dim sum was fresh and pretty darn good for delivery. We will  be back again, delivery was 20 minutes, can't beat that!
Veggie egg rolls were very good too.
author: Pug P.

description:
2.0 considering that I can have it delivered. Without delivery, it would be a 1.5.

Fairly bland dishes that are reasonably edible. I ate what I ordered (fyi, delivery to Noe took ages), but it was more from hunger and laziness than anything else. But heck, it was fairly inexpensive, large portions, and they deliver dim sum. Not bad, not great.
author: Sabine S.

description:
I order from here on a regular basis, and yes I am a fan.

The delivery is always prompt - the only place I know that delivers faster than they quote, not longer.

The food is good and very consistent, and I must say the chow mein and mongolian beef  are great the next day heated up in the microwave.

Cheap, quick and plenty of food.  Everything I look for in Chinese take out.
author: David R.

description: This place has great food.  And they deliver for free.  The ambiance of the restaurant is okay.  But if you're going for food...this is the place to go!
author: Christina B.

description: i love jasmine tea house. their food is extremely good, and the service is so friendly. the dining room is quite pleasant, an their delivery is always very fast. i'm vegan, and all of their veggie dishes and faux meats are stellar, but their dim sum is where it's at. best veggie dim sum in sf (along with big lantern in inner mission). sadly, the new menu has omitted some of my favorite veggie options, but what's left is still delicious. all day, amazing, veggie dim sim delivery? heaven...
author: joey e.

description:
New to the area and was looking for some decent Chinese food in the when we came upon Jasmine Tea House on yelp.  Most of the reviews were decent so we figured we'd give it a shot.... unfortunately it was a mistake.

We ordered the pork buns, combination wonton soup, pork fired rice, and beef with broccoli.  A bunch of basic items that are pretty hard to make bad, but this place succeeded.

The pork buns were all bun and no pork with very minimal flavor. This was the highlight of the meal.

The wonton soup looked like it had leftover meat thrown on top from a bunch of different types dishes.  What was supposed to be beef I didn't even recognize.  The container was jam packed with wontons, meat scraps, and a few veges with a little broth non of which had any flavor or good texture.  the secret to good wonton soup is keep it light, keep it simple and have great but not overpowering flavor and this had none of that.

Next we tried the beef with broccoli.  I took two bites of this dish and immediately stopped eating.  The texture of the meat was not even recognizable of beef and had no good flavor what so ever.  The broccoli was all over cooked and the sauce was thick and once again... tasted of nothing.

lastly I tried the pork fried rice which I thought could not in any way be as bad as the other items.  The good news is that it wasn't as bad, but it still was not good.  The only flavor the dish contained was that of oil.  no soy sauce, no egg, no onion, no pork... just oil.  after four bites I was done.

so after paying about $30 I had eaten about 12 bites of food and decided I couldn't eat any more of it.  I packed it all back up, tossed it in the trash and threw in a frozen pizza, which is sad to say was much cheaper and much more delicious than my take home meal from Jasmine Tea House.
author: Lamar H.

description:
OMG.  So we were starving last night and ordered delivery.   Basil Chicken and some other chicken dish + egg rolls.

The egg rolls were ok, but egads - the main dishes were not only exactly the same (vegetables & flavor - other than the basil chicken had basil) but wow - it was all very bland, a bit overcooked and stew-y.  We struggled to finish half of our portions (and we were really hungry!).

Alas - so we made a huge mistake.  To ensure it never happens again, we threw away the menu and will NEVER order again.  Unfortunately, I can't imagine that being at the restaurant is going to be substantially different, so will certainly never go.
author: Nancy R.

description: One my local favorite restaurants to eat for lunch while at work.  I've tried many of the items on the menu and I'm never disappointed.  They also serve brown rice which is a big thumbs up.
author: Ricky M.

description: Won't go back there. While the appetizer rolls were tasty my main dish, a red curry dish, was sodium laden. I also had some minor digestive problems after eating there.
author: dunz r.

description:
Most of the Jasmine Tea House's customers are clearly phone order, given the majority of human activity in the dining room is a steady stream of delivery guys. While this is a good reason to run a good delivery business, I can't say I've ever gotten consistent quality from any delivery restaurant. 
They get waaay too little traffic in the dining room from eat-in customers, and it's actually a pretty nice place. And the food is very good quality for the price, and they carry a lot of specialty items. While I've had some delivered food be disappointing, it's bound to happen, and I think JTH is more consistent than average. If it's good enough for Billary, it's good enough for me.
author: Kaya d.

description:
106 Reviews on this place for a reason.

Try the general tofu. Its simply amazing and blows my vegetarian friends minds when I take them here.   It's been one of my favourite places to eat for the last 3-4 years. I even venture on the bus to the mission just to eat here. Risking my life! :]
author: Brian D.

description:
I eat here at least once a month and the food is always good.  

Fresh ingredients, even the chicken is not manky.  My favorites are the wonton noodle soup, potstickers, mandarin claypot, and sizzling beef.  The staff is always very friendly.
author: May M.

description:
This place rocks. My friend introduced me to it with some takeout, which arrived in like 15 minutes--he lives just two block away. Since then, visited the place four times times and have never had a problem and loved everything we ordered. I really like General Tsao's Chicken and Mongolian Beef. They also have quite a few veggie dishes. 

Last time I went, I brought some buddies on a visit from Vancouver and they loved it. One had to stay cut for a shoot coming up, and they made him some steamed veggie dish. Everyone was really happy, especially when bill came out to less than $7 per person with drinks.
author: Boris K.

description:
Not bad, not good.  I've gotten take out from them twice and both times have been under-impressed, although not grossed out.  The mock chicken is not going to please any conneisseurs of mock-chicken (or other fake-meats), but all right - easily edible at least.

They've been fast and nice, selection is okay.  If they were a bit cheaper I would probably eat here again, but for $10+ entrees I'll find someplace tastier.

Their fortunes in tha fortune cookies are super-lame though - really bland, generic, and sappy.
author: Tmon B.

description:
One of our delivery stand-bys, but it's also pleasant to eat at, disproving the general rule that good Chinese restaurants have to have a noisy, chaotic ambiance. 

Vegi dishes count as entrees. For delivery, two entrees = one free order of fried rice or chow mein/fun. So you can get the basil ostrich and the garlic spinach (both highly recommended), and they'll throw in a free order of beef chow fun. Yowza! What's with the folks calling it pricey?

Jasmine is far less greasy than most of the nearby Chinese places; you can get yucky sweet & sour whatever, but that's your own fault for ordering something predestined to be cloying. If you're dining there, they have a well thought-out tea selection and interesting dim sum. Shrimp/banana roll? Why not?
author: Ess D.

description: Awesome, quick Chinese food--not much more you can ask for from a neighborhood joint that delivers.  The food is great, the sweet & sour pork and General Tso's Chicken come crispy without too much breading.  The veggies are always fresh and the meal isn't too heavy.
author: Don N.

description: Some of the BEST Chinese food I have had in a long time.  I am gluten free and it is sometimes difficult to eat chinese.  I was able to order anything off the menu and they were able to accommodate me!  I had the garlic chicken and the veggie fried rice.  Just amazing!!  Erin had sesame beef she says "it was really tasty - not too fatty and slightly sweet and crispy."
author: Julie C.

description:
I have eaten at Jasmine Tea House only once, however, I've eaten the food many times. I prefer to get their food delivered as it is fast and free. There are so many great options to choose from we try something new every time. But the go-to foods we almost always get include the Korean wings and the duck.

The dim sum is good as well.

I've never had anything that I absolutely didn't like and all the food seems fresh and made with high-quality ingredients.

A warning about the fried rice and chow mein, however. Although tasty, they are both very dry. We often end up adding soy sauce when we get it (it comes free if you order enough food).

Overall this is a solid Chinese restaurant with a good selection of unique specials worth giving a try.
author: Megan C.

description: Best place ever to have Combo Wonton soup I LOVE IT!!!! :) I go with a group of friends and we always order a few different plates and share because they are pretty packed! I love the combo fried rice too wit lots of the spicy sauce! YUM!
author: Johana R.

description: In a neighborhood full of great Chinese food, this place stands out. The best chow mein in all of Noe / Bernal / Outer Mission. And mammoth portions.
author: B G.

description: Very disappointed.  Unfortunately I didn't have a chance to try their food but their service for delivery is horrible.  I tried ordering through grubhub, the restaurant called me to tell me it was going to be an hour an half wait (I was in the other room and didn't pick up the phone).  And they cancelled my order.   I'm fine with that.  They were being proactive.  But then when still trying to place the order again, they refused to put me towards the front of the line and said I had to wait another hour and a half, after already waiting almost 2 hours.  Stubborn, petty and horrible service.   I hope the food makes up for it.  Grubhub gave me good service, Jasmine Tea House came up short.
author: Daniel S.

description: Food was outstanding and the waiter was very entertaining. Plus, free dessert...woo hoo! Fried bananas with chocolate sauce...delicioso! Started with the crab puffs and some sake...you know it! Scallops in garlic sauce some asparagus beef with giant mushrooms and lemon chicken...man! I'm hungry all over again...Well done Jasmine, well done!
author: Bane V.

description:
After I went vegetarian 7 years ago I gave up lemon chicken, until a year ago I discovered Jasmine Tea House.

Amazing:
lemon chicken
sweet 'n sour chicken
kung pao tofu (to die for)
servers
delivery service (fast and free!)

yay for us vegans.
author: Gina H.

description:
I like Chinese food. I really like authentic Chinese food. Don't come here looking for this. This is your standard Americanized Chinese fare- Mu shu, broccoli beef, orange chicken- but they do it well. Fresh ingeredients, large portions, not big puddles of grease at the bottom of your plate. Very solid place.

With free delivery, I can see myself ordering from here often.
author: Evan B.

description:
I love the fact that when you call to order the man is practically singing... but they deliver within reason and they are good! This is a cute neighborhood rest. with very nice staff, all the way to the delivery people.
They have a number of dishes that are quite memorable.... I like the Mango Shrimp Salad, I know who goes to Chinese to eat salad... well I do! they have a number of vegetarian dishes that are yummy although I am not a vegetarian. I do not like over cooked vegetables which they do not have a problem with, even with delivery.
author: Karen E.

description:
We have tried delivery Chinese twice before since we moved to the Outer Mission in Dec.  Both times the food was OK at best.  We get menus on our stair case for places all the time and have felt like maybe we should just start throwing them in the recycle bin.  Tonight we really felt like Chinese food, but wanted to be able to drink as much sake and beer as we wanted.  I mean, it is Saturday night and fortunately we are responsible adults!  We decided to do some homework on YELP tonight before we tried Chinese delivery one last time. 

YEAH!  We finally found our place.  Our fellow YELP'ers didn't steer us wrong.  The food was great & well priced.  It took almost an hour for our food to come, but we figured that it would take that long given it is Sat.  The food came hot and yummy.  And you can't beat the free delivery and fried rice with the order.  (Min order applies.)

We for sure will be ordering from this place again.  (And heating up some sake and drinking some Tsingtao's safely from home!)
author: Kathleen F.

description: I LUV LUV LUV this place!!! Everything on the menu is fantastic trust me I've eaten damn near everything on it. The won ton soup is one a kind, The crab puffs are thee bomb!!!! I can't rave enough about this place. Customer service is great and the prices are reasonable.
author: nadia p.

description:
It is not "gourmet," but it is damn good!  Very fair prices.  No MSG.  And they deliver!

My very personal favorite is the calamari.  It is always tender and has a good (but not healthy!) batter dipped and fried coating.  They serve it with sliced hot pepper that makes for a good, spicy taste.  Their sauces are also good.

I also strongly recommend the shrimp dumpling dim sum.  

Other items that I have tried and liked:  hot and sour soup, veggie fried rice.

Check out their menu here:  http://www.jasmineteahouse.com/menu.html
author: Tom S.

description: Good food.  Good service.  Close to my job.  I go about twice a month and always leave with a smile on my face.  The waiters are friendly and helpful.  So far the best on the lunch menu is the garlic eggplant.  The basil chicken is also very good.  Large portions...i usually leave with half my meal in a to go box.
author: Glenn B.

description: Mmmmm, this place is gooood! I just went there this past weekend with my boyfriend and we loved it. We ordered potstickers (half veggi for me and half pork for him) the veggi fried rice to share, "meatless" orange chicken for me, and he ordered the basil ostrich. The potstickers were really yummy because they tasted homemade (they were big and doughy and filled generously) and the "meatless" chicken tasted awesome. Even my boyfriend who is a big meat eater liked it. In all, everything was really delicious and the waiter we had was nice. Hope to return soon!!
author: Audrey H.

description:
best chinese delivery in the area.  I detest fake meat.....and I swear I could NOT tell the difference between my roommate's fake sesame chicken and my regular chicken.  Green beans were also great.  Make sure to ask for the fried rice.  Also they can make any of their chicken dishes with the fake chicken, not just what is listed on the menu.  Yum!

Edited to add - 
last time I ordered from here it was really not good.  I am moving on to try new places....
author: Emily d.

description:
This place is great for having food delivered up the mighty Bernal hill.
They've got great dim sum, and appetizers, as well as some good spicy dishes. If you order a certain amount of food, you get free fried rice, or chow mein(get the fried rice) it's better, plus it's free.
author: Meagen H.

description: This place is one of the better chinese restaurants in my neighborhood.  The prices here are fare and the portions are hearty.  Their orange chicken is made with real orange peels not like that panda express crap.  When ordering take out they have a coupon for free fried rice or chow mein for orders of $20 or more.  The fried rice is good enough to feed 2-3 people.
author: Cedric F.

description: Love, love, LOVE this place! So my favorite city boy ever has taken me here throughout the last 5years and I have yet to yelp it, oops? We've eaten here and ordered takeout many times over and every time it's on POINT. It's definitely a bit pricier than most because other than lunch they don't offer any kind of dinner specials and it's all single entrees. This past Friday I ordered the Sizzling Rice soup and crab puffs, omfg! SOOO full and happy, let me tell you! It's always a delight to come in here as well because the staff is warm and friendly, and since homeboy grew up in the area and gives them plenty of business they sure do welcome him LOL. Gotta introduce more of my Bay Areans to this amazing establishment.
author: Nancy R.

description:
There are so many good dishes at this restaurant. My favorite is the Wor Wonton Soup. It probably has something to do with the seasoning of the beef, chicken, pork and prawn sauté that is mixed into the soup, but the broth has so much more flavor than the traditional clear vegetable/chicken stock found in most wonton soups. Other ingredients that can be found in the soup include carrots, baby bok choi, snow peas and mushrooms. If you like busy dishes, this is definitely a winner. 

I am a big fan of Generals Chicken and I have only been to a few places that use all white meat chicken chunks compared to the KFC popcorn style chicken pieces used at most Chinese restaurants. Here it is served with big pieces of tender chicken, covered with a crispy shell. 

Other notable dishes include the Szechwan Beef, Scallops with Garlic Sauce, and the House Spicy Chow Mein.

I also liked the following vegetable dishes; chinese broccoli with oyster sauce, garlic spinach, garlic eggplant, and the baby bok choi in garlic sauce.
author: Francis A.

description:
Yum yum yum! My favorite Chinese delivery food place in the Mission/Bernal/Potrero area.  Plus they have some great dim sum! I don't think I've ever gotten anything here that I don't like. 

Delivery is really fast and the delivery people are nice.  Eat-in is fine, although the place is kind of generic (although clean and comfortable).

Really glad this place is there!
author: Rusty H.

description:
Oh Jasmine Tea House how I love you.

Ok well this wonderful outer mission spot has the love of former president Bubba Clinton. Now if the former prez. will order twice in one night please allow me to elaborate on his wonderful reasoning. Jasmine in my opinion offers the best vegetarian/non-vegetarian combination of mandarin style food in the mission. I'm almost more than certain basil "tofu/chicken/fake chicken" is what got the former pres' attention. It is by far the most repeatably delectable dish on jasmine's menu. As a meat eater who often takes the wheat gluten route to switch things around I can say both options are awesome. I've even reached so far as to try the basil Ostrich and if you like gamey bird then this is your place. I've seen others mention them as well, I somehow manage to polish off a full plate of crab rangoon every time I go here, I just can't help it. Did I mention the veggie mu shu? This establishment just keeps rollin em' out so many winners and very few losers. For those of you on the financially constrained side of the spectrum lunch is the best bang for your buck including dim sum, rice and entree specials w/free sweet & sour soup. real Jasmine tea is always nice and lastly the fact if I'm really that lazy I can order out? If your in the mission I smite thee for even thinking of going to any other chinese food place before jasmine. Seriously! Don't be lazy walk your ass over here and enjoy some great food
author: James M.

description: Great food, always been fast service, and really nice servers. Prices are a little above the usual price for Chinese food, but this is quality and well worth it!
author: Tim R.

description: Very good Chinese, with an extensive menu. Many of the dishes are huge (Singapore noodles are about 4 meals in one). Walnut shrimp are so tasty but covered in an unusually large amount of fried batter - beware.
author: E T.

description: Dining at asmine Tea House is like dining at my vegetarian grandmother's house. Sure she also serves meat, but sometimes I wonder, as all of their fake meat is incredibly passable. Flavorful, great service, reasonable pricing, fast delivery (and they deliver all the way to SOMA/FiDi!!!)  Nothing but love for the Jasmine Tea House!
author: Michael H.

description: EDIT: i've since been discouraged by their abysmal health inspection scores: http://sf.everyblock.com/restaurant-inspections/filter/by-restaurant-dba/jasmine%20tea%20house/
author: joe b.

description: If I could give it  none, I would.  Disgusting, greasy, dripping in sauces, not fresh at all.  Plus cold when delivered.   Would NEVER order from here again.
author: Kelly B.

description: I've had takeout from Jasmine Tea House about 500 times. Maybe it just seems like 500. Their meatless chicken is amazing. A-ma-zing! Even my husband (president of poultry eaters of America) likes it. I'm craving it right now, so I will cut this short so I can get them on the horn. They are one of my favorite things about my 'hood. Two blocks to fake chicken heaven. You can't ask for more than that.
author: Abby W.

description:
Some will say that this is Chinese American fare, but I'm not one of them; seems like when people describe 'real' Chinese food, they pick places that seem to think the Chinese culinary point of view requires a 1/2 cup of canola oil for every stir-fry dish.  Um, no. I'm Chinese and I'm happy to pass on the grease and the MSG.  
But I won't pass on good loose leaf tea - which Jasmine Tea House certainly has. I tried a one called 'gunpowder' tonight - a smokier green tea, a nice change from Jasmine (eeeeverybody's got Jasmine, snooze).
And I definitely require perfectly sauteed garlic spinach - a wee bit on the underdone side, not all limp with it's moisture pooling at the bottom of the plate, and well seasoned.  
The Yangtze spareribs I tried was just ok to me, but the meat was cooked well, tearing from the bone easily.  
I also tried a dim sum combo - again, just ok. 
There was a LOT to choose from on the menu, some typical, some really unusual, that I think I'll have to revisit another 4, maybe 5 times to be real certain of this place.
But the lovely decor, nicely attentive staff, and decent prices will make it an easy return destination.
author: CINDY K.

description: I thought this was a dim sum joint, but it's more of a Chinese restaurant that has a small selection of dim sum. I was disappointed, but I went ahead and looked at their dozen or so selection. The shrimp stuffed bell pepper and shu mai caught my attention. My party of 3 shared that along with 3 other dishes. The Mongolian beef was ok, not spicy at all and more on the sweeter side, garlic fish was pretty good, and the roast duck was fatty and not fresh. The dim sum were ok, but it wasn't the freshest, understandably so. They gave huge rice portions with the food. The service was attentive & friendly and the place was clean. . Really nothing much more to say...
author: Freckles H.

description: Meatless sesame chicken? How can this exist?? It's seriously finger-licking good & I don't care what's in it!!
author: Chrissy L.

description: Meatless Chicken. Sounds not so good but turns out to be amazingly tasty. Big fan. Huge.
author: Kelly S.

description: i really like it here. deemed it one oft favorite chinese restaurants haha. my first time at jasmine tea house was w my boyfriend an his family; had Mongolian beef over fried rice &i asked them to not make it spicy. turned out good. next time I went, I ordered sweet and sour chicken which is heaven in your mouth. there was one time tho when me and my boyfriends family went to eat there for lunch-- me and my boyfriend shared a rice plate and his brother and mom had their own. at the end, we were given three fortune cookies. it's like one fortune cookie for each plate lol. I was like wth? arrite! but other than their stinginess on fortune cookies, this restaurant has very courteous waiters and hosts and a nice dining environment.
author: lib c.

description: I've eaten here for years and enjoyed it. Sadly, last night I got food poisoning from an order of shrimp shu mai.  As tasty as it can be, bad shellfish is a huge turn off.
author: Sasha H.

description: Regular american chinese food like you wd imagine getting when you order it.  The lunch specials are obviously a great deal too. I went in recently since it had been closed for a while renovations. Met jasmine tea  new owner who is a former longtime employee who wants it to be like it always used to be. I like the meatless chicken general tsao here more than some other places but everything is really fine and good and just what you wd imagine. Also no msg which is a major plus.
author: Precita M.

description: So we decided to try this place out tonight.  We found their flyer banded to our front gate not long ago and their menu sat in my drawer until today.  We ordered our food, it arrived in a reasonable amount of time, but found the food to be underwhelming.  It was warm, plain and greasy.  Disappointing.  Our search for good take-out/delivery continues.
author: Denny L.

description: Me so hungry, me love you long time.  With that said, the food and service here are good.  You can choose anything from Mongolian beef, mango salad, hot & sour soup, and a bunch of other delicious treats.  Those are just a few of my favorites.  Bonuses: they have awesome lunch specials at great prices.  A must eat!
author: Victoria S.

description: Favorite Chinese delivery in the city. Particularly awesome highlights: Happy Buddha, Basil Ostrich, and Dry Garlic Calamari. Joy!
author: Abie H.

description: I used to get delivery from Jasmine & actually thought that the food (meatless chicken, veggie/tofu dishes) was pretty good... But a 44 health score?!?! Shouldn't a place be closed down if the score is THAT low? Never again. http://dph-extranet2.sfdph.org:7777/pls/eeop_htmldb/f?p=132:2:3728735458498896::NO::P2_LOCATIONID:2680
author: Marybeth S.

description: Good food, decent service, lots of veggie options, and their house made faux meat is really really good. Some of the best Ive had outside of Bamboo Garden in Seattle!I had a cup of vegetable soup, shared some meatless potstickers and the Happy Buddha!! Really good mix of veggies too, not the uber-lame celery, onion, carrot combo you sometimes find in sad Asian food.
author: Rebecca L.

description: Another totally dissapointing entry in SF's take out Chinese scene. I used to order from this place every once in a while when I lived in the Mission and while I could stomach it, I was never excited. I liked the *idea* of it, but not the execution. Only thing I can remember enjoying (but only slightly) was the Mu-Shu.
author: Maria D.

description: I've been holing myself up over the weekend trying to study for a test next week, but a girl's gotta eat!  A few yelpy minutes later, I find Jasmine Tea House.  Their menu was clearly posted online, and I ordered the General Tsao Chicken and the combination Hong Kong Noodles.  The food arrived about 35 minutes after I placed the order.  The delivery guy was all smiles and super pleasant when he dropped the food off.  There was seriously enough food for at least 4 meals (so good value)!  The chicken came still crispy and well-sauced.  The noodles had a good amount of beef, seafood, and veggies.  Actually, everything was surprising tasty for chinese delivery!  whooohoooo!  I would definitely order again!
author: Amy C.

description: OPEN!!!  The service and people are awsome. The food is great and I am so happy that Jasmine is open again. Thank you!
author: Theresa S.

description: What is it with the inconsistency of Chinese food delivery in this town?  I've had decent food from JTH before, but have been experimenting with others in search of the divine.  The high ratings of fellow yelpers enticed me to call them again.  Ugh.  The kung pao shrimp was bland, no spice, veggies too soft.  The potstickers were doughy devoid of flavor.  Veggie fried rice?  Yeah, it was fine for being free...  and don't get me started on the spareribs, I threw them away.  I'm a sad, sad yelper today.
author: Julie L.

description: YUM!  Way better than Eric's in Noe Valley...and what a deal!!  They deliver for an order of $12 or more and give free fried rice or chow mein if you order 2 entrees!!!  What a bargain!
author: Tabatha Y.

description: Yet another wonderful food experience with Jasmine tea house! To go was great! They are always soooo nice and welcoming.
author: Rosy D.

description: I agree with Bill Clinton: Jasmine Tea House is the truth! This is by far my favorite Chinese delivery in the city. The green onion pancake is a chunk of fried bliss and the general Tsao chicken is addictive. However, the general Tsao has been inconsistent lately, which isn't a bad thing, but can be confusing. For instance, sometimes it's more breaded and/or saucy than others. It's all gravy though because this chicken is always tasty. The veggie fried rice compliments any entree well. You can also dine in-house to enjoy the reasonable lunch specials.
author: Adam L.
